Award.AwardTitle: Bacterial Chemotaxis in Complex Dynamical Landscapes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Chemical signals from a cell's environment can induce motion of that cell. This phenomenon, called chemotaxis, in the E. coli bacteria is one of the most extensively studied biological response. The E. coli chemotaxis network has become a paradigm for cellular behavior and signal transduction pathways and in this project the PI aims to understand signaling and behavior in E. coli considering them in the context of their function and the specific challenges they have evolved to address. The current experimental project is motivated by a recent theoretical work by the PI, which applies advanced tools of statistical physics to such biological problems. In the proposed experiments, a chemotaxis assay of a new type will be specially built to test those key predictions of the new theory. This project has the potential to change a widely accepted part of the paradigm of E.coli chemotaxis and possibly change the perspective on directed motion of other cells and organisms. The study synergistically combines theoretical analysis, innovative microfluidic technology, microbiology and molecular biology techniques, quantitative experiments with cells, and advanced microscopy and data analysis. The PI and Co-PI have complementary areas of expertise and have known each other for more than a decade from their previous work on mixing in chaotic and turbulent flows. Graduate students will be trained in cross-disciplinary environment and benefit from the synergism of the two groups involved in the proposed project with their complementary areas of expertise. The PIs will also continue to be involved in education, instruction and training that closely interface with the proposed work.

The project is an experimental study of the role of adaptation in chemotaxis of Escherichia coli in different types of gradients of chemo-attractants and of adaptation in aerotaxis and pH-taxis of E. coli. A remarkable feature of E. coli chemotaxis is the perfect adaptation to changes in the concentration of aspartate, a commonly used attractant. The response of E. coli to a short-term change in aspartate concentration has asymmetric positive and negative lobes, with the integral equal to zero. The proposed experimental study is driven by a recent theoretical analysis by the PI, showing that the main advantage of the perfect adaptation is optimal navigation through environments with time-varying, complex spatial distributions of nutrients. Environments of this type are likely to be present in liquid E. coli cultures at the entry to the stationary phase, where E. coli motility is at its maximum. This analysis represents an alternative to a common narrative that the main function of the perfect adaptation is the retention of sensitivity to shallow gradients over a broad range of background concentrations. The theoretical predictions will be tested with a two-pronged experimental approach. First, chemotaxis of freely swimming wild-type and mutated E. coli will be studied in static linear profiles of attractants, for which the perfect adaptation is predicted to be non-optimal. Therefore, perfectly adapted E. coli are expected to have lower chemotactic efficiency than some of imperfectly adapted E. coli. Second, E. coli chemotaxis will be studied in a custom-built microfluidic device, which creates time-varying spatially non-uniform gradients of attractants. Based on the theory, the perfectly adapted E. coli are expected to outperform all competitors, securing highest average concentrations of the attractant along their swimming trajectories. The experiments will be facilitated by a technique recently developed by the PI that extracts temporal responses from trajectories of freely swimming cells. The proposed study will also apply this technique to the analysis directed motion of E. coli in well-defined gradients of oxygen and pH in a microfluidic device recently built by the Co-PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report on the Grant 1411313 ?Bacterial Chemotaxis in Complex Dynamical Landscapes? supported by the NSF Program Physics of Living Systems

Like other living organisms, bacteria seek environments with best conditions to survive and thrive. Motile bacteria evolved capabilities to sense relevant environmental factors, like nutrients, acidity/basicity (pH), oxygen, and temperature, and to actively migrate following their spatial changes (gradients). The general name for these migrations is ?taxis?. The best-studied of them is the chemo-taxis of the bacterium Escherichia coli in spatial gradients of chemicals (chemo-attractants). Conversely, migration in gradients of temperature (thermo-taxis), has been explored relatively little, partly because of technical difficulties of exposing bacteria to thermal gradients that are both well-controlled and sufficiently steep to elicit a robust response. The goals of our project were to address and advance the state of the art for both chemo- and thermo-taxis, and to provide opportunities for the development of human resources, which were all successfully achieved.

For chemotaxis, while much is known at the molecular levels, much less was known on its physiological and evolutionary role, which was our main focus. First, we experimentally examined the consequences of chemical landscapes? properties. This led to publications in PLOS Computational Biology and an invited review in Current Opinion in Microbiology. By comparing the gradient-climbing speed of bacteria in constant chemoattractant profiles, we supported theoretical arguments that we developed in previous work, and ruled out oft-heard arguments on chemotaxis being needed for climbing long and static gradients. That opened up the path to more recent work, where we identified a new role for chemotaxis as promoting the expansion of bacterial populations into unoccupied territories. Results were published in 2019 in Nature. While swimming characteristics of individual cells were found to be nearly constant across a range of conditions supporting exponential growth, the speed of collective migration, as exemplified by the propagation of rings in nutrient-replete soft agar plates, increased steadily with improved growth conditions. Our quantitative experiments and modeling revealed an intricate balance of growth, motility, and chemotaxis, giving rise to a coherent population-level dynamics which not only maintained the fast propagation of the ring, but seeded an exponentially rising density of bacteria trailing the ring. Consumable chemoattractants act then as aroma-like cues, establishing the direction and enhancing the speed of expansion along their self- generated gradients at the expanding front, where the density of bacteria is relatively high. This navigated range expansion spreads significantly faster and provides a significant boost to population growth compared to unguided expansion in the absence of chemotaxis, which is widely assumed in canonical models of range expansion. Our new mechanism is then important both fundamentally and for its ecological consequences.

As for thermo-taxis, we designed and built a microfluidic experimental setup, in which robust and well-defined linear thermal gradients of different steepness were generated across microchannels. E. coli cells along the microchannel were allowed sufficient time to explore the cross-channel temperature field and use their thermotactic prowess to aggregate at their preferred temperature. We used the setup to perform an extensive study of thermotaxis of E. coli in a broad range of linear gradients. Its main results were published in Biophysical Journal in 2020 and are as follows. (1) In shallow thermal gradients spanning narrow temperature ranges, thermotaxis is weak, and E. coli tend to aggregate at the highest or lowest temperature. (2) In steeper gradients, spanning sufficiently broad ranges that include temperatures between 35 and 40 ?C, which are optimal for E. coli growth, cells aggregate at intermediate temperatures. Importantly, this aggregation at an intermediate temperature was not expected from results of previous studies and we were the first to report it. (3) Even more surprisingly, we observed that, as the gradients became steeper, the E. coli aggregation temperatures steadily decreased, from 40 ?C for the shallowest gradient to 30 ?C for the steepest gradient tested. We were not able to explain this behavior, which shows how incomplete is

our current understanding of the relatively well-studied migration of E. coli. A byproduct of this study is a characterization of thermophoresis of fluorescent dye molecules in linear thermal gradients and unintended effect of the thermophoresis upon measurements of temperature with a microscopic resolution using these dyes. The microfluidic setup was also used in another collaborative study on E. coli thermotaxis, which was focused on molecular mechanisms and signal transduction. The results of this study were published in eLife in 2017. In addition, the NSF funding partially supported yet another collaborative project that involved high-resolution longitudinal imaging of Caenorhabditis elegans worms to study the formation of cellular compartments in germline cells of these round worms. The results of this study were published in eLife in 2018.
